dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO BOYS sit on opposite sides of a chessboard.  One is N the other FOURTEEN.  The room is SILENT, the tension betw the two young players severe.  All the ADULT PLAYERS that been eliminated from this match by the two boys stand aro watching.  On the wall is a BANNER that reads:  1972 WASH STATE TOURNAMENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FOURTEEN year old moves and hits his TIMER.  Frustrat fills the NINE year old's face.  He moves.  The FOURTEEN old moves and calls CHECK.  The NINE year old frantically searches the board for a solution.  He moves.  Again the FOURTEEN year old moves and calls CHECK.  The NINE year i stunned.  He picks up his KING to lay it on it's side and signal defeat.  Suddenly, he rakes the pieces off the boa grabs his fountain pen and lunges at the FOURTEEN year ol stabbing him repeatedly in the chest.  They fall to the f The ADULTS try to pull them apart.  The NINE year old str ferociously, SCREAMING and kicking like a mad man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the b.g. we see the Nine year old Boy sleeping.  A DOC and the boy's FATHER, a hard-looking MAN in his forties, through the door.  We MOVE with them down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pressures and demands players with your son's abilities put on themselves to win are incredible.  The stress and tension are difficult enough for adults to handle, yet alone a nine year old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't afford to keep him in here forever, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just like to keep him here over night, then start sessions with a child psychologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew this would happen.  This is his mother's doing.  She's not strict enough with him.  I work all day.  She lays in bed drunk and the boy does whatever he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After he's released it's crucial that he's supervised.  The most important thing is that during his treatment he's not allowed anywhere near a chessboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, tract home.  The Boy sits on the ground, drawing the dirt with a stick.  He does not notice as his Father up and stands behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy is startled.  He stands up quickly.  In the DIRT he has drawn a CHESSBOARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Father SLAPS him across the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lie to me!  What did the doctor's tell you about playing chess!  Get in the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Father drags his foot across the dirt, erasing the bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy is sitting on his bed.  In the b.g. we HEAR the V of his PARENTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had it!  I've got a drunk for a wife and a lunatic for a son.  I don't need this shit anymore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR FOOTSTEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy!  Both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR a DOOR SLAM.  The Boy shows no sign of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is quiet except for a faint DRIPPING SOUND.  A door i slowly opened.  Light streaks out into a hallway.  We see NINE year old.  He is barefoot and wearing pajamas.  He l up.  Drops of BLOOD drip from a crack in the ceiling abov The Boy moves towards a staircase at the end of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy enters, takes a few steps into the room and stops stares ahead blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arm hangs off the bed, blood flows out of a deep gash her wrist and pools on the floor.  The CAMERA moves up th A WOMAN in her forties lays in bed.  The blood flows from other wrist, soaking into the mattress.  Her eyes are clo head titled away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy shows no sign of emotion.  He walks over to the nightstand and starts to open her purse.  There is a MOAN the WOMAN as she opens her eyes and turns her head toward boy.  They lock eyes for a moment, then slowly, her eyes The boy removes a key from the purse and walks to a dress He unlocks a drawer and removes a box, then leaves the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy walks over to the table with a glass of MILK and COOKIES.  He sits down, his feet dangling from the chair opens the box.  Inside is a CHESSBOARD and PIECES.  He re them, sets up the board and starts to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON CHESSBOARD:  The CAMERA moves from one side of t board to the other, weaving through the chess pieces, the PULLS BACK over the heads of the AUDIENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: >From the rear of the room, over the HEADS of the AUDIENC see THREE TABLES on stage.  A large board of the game is presented on the wall behind each table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - PLAYER'S EYES:  We cut back and forth.  Deep probing eyes, intensely focused and determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE CLOCK: It ticks methodically, and is the onl sound we hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE AUDIENCE:  watches with anticipation, their eyes lock the viewing board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETER SANDERSON sits on one side of the board.  He is a handsome man, in his early thirties.  Well-dressed in an expensive suit, there is an air of confidence about him. makes a move, then hits the timer.  Peter's opponent, GRANDMASTER LUTZ, a quirky-looking little man in his fift makes a tentative move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JEREMY EDMONDS, Peter's trainer, a distinguished-looking his fifties, watches from his WHEELCHAIR.  He grins and n his head, knowing that Peter has got the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lutz studies the board, makes a move, then hits his timer Peter moves, then hits his timer.  He is in control. Frustration shows on Lutz's face.  He surveys the board, slowly reaches over and lifts up his KING and lays it on side signaling defeat.  Peter stands, shakes his hand, wa the crowd, then leaves the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NEWSCASTER is positioned by the stage door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today concludes the second week of competition in this round-robin candidates tournament.  Each of the players will play four games against the other and the winner will earn the right to play for the world title next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks through the doorway and down the hall, accept congratulations.  Jeremy wheels himself along side of him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the big story is the amazing comeback of Peter Sanderson who is currently leading the tournament. America's best hope since Bobby Fischer, Sanderson stunned the chess world three years ago when he walked out in the middle of last candidates tournament while leading by three games and forfeited the match to Viktor Yurilivich who is only two games behind Sanderson in this match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stops to sign a few autographs.  A young attractive in her twenties walks over to Peter.  She is wearing a CH FEDERATION BLAZER and a NAME TAG identifying her as DEBI RUTLEGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Sanderson, here is your schedule for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes it.  They lock eyes.  She smiles at him.  A REPORTER sticks a MICROPHONE in Peter's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, could we have a moment please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment is broken, as ERICA SANDERSON, Peter's daughte bright-faced ten year rushes up to him and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the press)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cheering section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits across a CHESSBOARD from Jeremy, who has just finished making an opening move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You opened with the English.  Lutz won't use it.  He opened his first game with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows you're aware of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll transpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a variation, yes -- but it must be a variation that is unique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you have something in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter gets up and begins to pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly moving the pieces)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point you'll move Bishop to e4. He'll capture your Knight e6.  Rook to b5, begins his counterplay.  D6 takes your Rook, your advantage is lost -- but watch -- Queen f5 check.  He takes your Knight -- Now, Rook to d3 -- he's finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK on the door and a MESSAGE is slipped und Peter picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good play, but risky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't win by playing it safe, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter opens the MESSAGE and reads it.  Erica appears in t doorway to her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't sleep.  My beds lumpy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  You forgot to bring you're night-light, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That has nothing to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to sleep in my bed tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tuck you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica kisses Peter, then runs into his room.  Jeremy whee after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy, have someone pick up a night- light tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi..?

dialogues.text: Peter and Debi move passionately on the bed, their bodies moving rhythmically.  Peter pulls her up to a sitting pos guiding her up and down as he runs his lips sensually ove breasts.  She arches her back, MOANING softly as she give to her pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter kisses Debi goodbye.  He walks off and she closes t door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi slips on a ROBE as she walks to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (static; barely audible)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and pushes the button, then opens the door, le it ajar, and walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dark.  She enters and tries the light switch.  It d work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON DEBI:  She senses something is very wrong.  She around slowly, her eyes squinting to see through the dark Suddenly, terror fills her face as a FLASH of BRIGHT LIGH fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quaint and charming.  Boats bob lazily in the water.  TOU walk along the waterfront shops.  ANDY WAGNER, a tough-lo cop in his twenties, smokes a cigarette as he waits on th dock.  CHIEF OF POLICE, FRANK SEDMAN, walks towards him. a large, slightly over-weight man in his forties.  He tak last drag of a cigar, then crushes it out on the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to ruin your trip to the city, but we got a real nut on our hands, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all business)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank starts to walk.  Andy follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at note-pad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi Rutlege.  Female.  Caucasian. Twenty four.  Worked over at the Four Oaks Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Local?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  She just moved here last month from Portland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several BLACK and WHITE units are in front of the buildin Uniformed OFFICERS keep back a CROWD of onlookers.  A CAR drives up and stops in front of the building.  Frank and get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with FORENSIC TEAM MEMBERS along with UNIFORM OFFICERS.  Frank enters with Andy.  UNIFORMED OFF are standing around talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a party.  Everybody that doesn't need to be here get out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank enters the room with Andy.  He stops and stares at sight before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debi Rutlege is laying on her bed.  Her face is a deathly and has been painted awkwardly with rouge and lipstick gi her a macabre appearance.  She is draped in the sheet whi tucked tightly around her body, her hands folded carefull across her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the bed written in blood is REMEMBER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I moved out here from the city so I could get away from this kind of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVE NOLAN, from the forensic team, who has been kneelin the other side of the bed stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whaddaya got, Nolan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; holding up a plastic bag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much.  There's no sign of a break in.  I think she let him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has she been dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six, eight hours tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any sign of rape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I can see.  We'll know more once I get the lab reports back from Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What she die of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nolan turns over her arms.  There are deep gashes in each wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think whoever did this wanted it to look like it was a suicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He would have taken more care not to the leave rope burns on her wrists. The way I got it figured is he tied her up, slit her wrists, then sat back and watched her bleed to death.  But that's not the main thing.  What's wrong with this picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Suddenly, Frank sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no blood.  Where's the fuckin' blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Andy walks across the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who found her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy points to MISS GREENWELL, a middle-aged woman talkin UNIFORMED OFFICER in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landlady.  Alice Greenwell.  She came for the rent check.  The door was ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank walks over to Miss Greenwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Greenwell, I'm Captain Sedman. Did Miss Rutlege have a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you guess so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she had company last night. (confidentially)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, her bedroom is on the other side of mine.  The walls are very thin.  I could hear them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were they doing?  Humping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were having sex, yes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- not that I was intentionally listening -- but  with the walls being so thin--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Andy stand before several UNIFORMED OFFICERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, I'd like to say that a lot of us haven't got to know each other since I replaced Captain Waters last month.  A lot of you think that I'm an outsider who came over and took away a job that should have gone to a local... but that's the way it worked out.  So, all I can say is tough shit. You want to bitch about it, that's fine -- but you will tow the line in my department.  That means the next time an Officer is responding to a homicide call he seals off the crime scene and nobody -- nobody but  but Detective Wagner and I go in. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, if anyone talks about the message on the wall or the blood I'll personally cut their balls off with a butter knife. (to Andy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get 'em going - then meet me at the car.  We're going over to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank heads to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell, you check with the FBI see if they got anything like this on file...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank steps into the hall and bumps into Nolan.  They wal together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much.  I don't think she was raped. There's no bruising, or any signs of trauma to the pelvic region -- and no trace of sperm which makes sense because she took a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about prints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, no prints but hers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Frank.  No prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is sitting at a chessboard with Jeremy.  Peter stud the board.  There is a KNOCK on the door.  Peter gets up opens the door.  Frank and Andy are outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Sanderson?  I'm Frank Sedman, Bainbridge P.D. and this is Detective Wagner.  We'd like to ask you a few questions about Debi Rutlege.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter opens the door and they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're busy so I'll get right to it.  Did you know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only in passing.  To say hello to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've talked to a few people who say you and her were... friendly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chess tournaments can be boring sometimes.  People have a lot of free time.  They like to gossip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you tell me where you were last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  I played Gregory Lutz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  You won two games against him and left the auditorium at eight forty five.  Where did you go after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my room and then I went for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank takes out a piece of paper from his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a printout from the hotel computer for all the messages logged to your room.  Here's one at 9:04 pm.  It says:  From Debi.  Please call me at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She called to give me my schedule for tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's interesting about it is you say you only knew her in passing.  Yet, she says on her message for you to call her at home and she doesn't leave a number. That would imply you already knew the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it from the tournament directory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank takes out a small book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no Debi Rutlege listed in the directory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's irritation starts to show.  He opens a dresser dr and removes a small book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking in the general directory.  The player's directory lists everyone connected to the tournament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Frank and Peter have reached a stalemate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We seem to have a little problem here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're lying.  That's what kind of problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not saying anything right now. We're just trying to put a few pieces together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Andy leave.  Peter turns and stares at Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Andy walk along the grounds, heading back towar main hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got an answer for everything, but he doesn't have an alibi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he's dirty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but I think you're right. He's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the stage is three tables each flanked by two chairs. Several CHESS OFFICIALS along with the PRESIDENT of the C FEDERATION attend to the GRANDMASTERS at their respective boards.  Peter sits in a chair and swivels back and forth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want another chair.  This one killed me yesterday. (points to big board)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, the pieces on the board move too slowly.  I can see them out of the corner of my eye.  Can they be sped up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID WILLERMAN, a computer technician sits at a computer to the side of the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.  It's just a matter of adjusting the response time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps in a few commands on the keyboard.  We see a piec quickly move across the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandmaster Lutz walks over and stands by the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're acting like a superstitious schoolboy, Peter.  What's next? Incense and rosary beads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to a chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandmaster Lutz, you'll be sitting here for your next match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no -- no, I can't sit there.  I must be facing North.  My power comes from the North.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter smiles and starts to walk off stage.  VIKTOR YURILI a tall, slender man in his forties, walks on stage.  The men stand face to face, their eyes locked on each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Peter.  You played an interesting game last night.  Even though sacrificing your Queen at b-5 is the game I played against Valsney in '82.  I'm glad it helped you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want you to do good.  That way when I beat you at the end I'll look that much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting sloppy, Yurilivich. You're nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you should be, because this time I'm going to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then this time you'll have to stay for the whole match, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits at a table across from Erica.  They play a gam checkers as they eat their ice cream.  Peter is grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lutz.  She also told me that Mr. Lutz goes to a medium to try and contact great Grandmasters in the spirit world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he gotten through to any?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but he did contact a dead parcheesi champion from Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both LAUGH.  A WAITER comes over with a CORDLESS PHO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a call for you Mister Sanderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "CALLERS" VOICE we HEAR is FILTERED through some type electronic devise that alters the voice.  It is low, reso with a macabre quality to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone who's going to become an important part of your life. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to play a game with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got time for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter starts to hang up, when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had time for Debi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I wiped off all your prints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter slowly lowers the phone back on the cradle.  He is visibly shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Peter walks across the room the DESK CLERK calls out t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Sanderson, there's message for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks over to the desk.  The Clerk hands him an env Peters walks away and starts to open it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT:  The back of a POLAROID PHOTOGRAPH.  Letters been clipped out of a magazine and spell out a message: GAME HAS BEGUN.  WILL CALL AGAIN TOMORROW AT ELEVEN.  The photograph is turned over.  It is a shot of DEBI RUTLEGE exactly as the police found her.  The word REMEMBER writt the wall.  Peter slides the picture back into the envelop thinks for a moment, then looks at the DESK CLERK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is with Frank and Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell us you were there earlier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I was afraid there'd be hours of questions.  I can't afford to miss a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't want someone's death to interfere with your games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your relationship with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casual?  You were boning her weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't serious.  What's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are!  I don't like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, don't ask me out on a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry I won't.  I've seen how your dates end up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes a step towards Andy.  They both square off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy.  Both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, this is just too convenient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means, if I were a killer and I thought the police were closing in on me I might invent someone to try and put them off the scent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's crazy!  Why would I draw attention to myself like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to play games, don't you, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says on the photo he'll call tomorrow at eleven.  Why not come back then and listen for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we'll be back.  You can bet on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits across from GRANDMASTER LUTZ.  He looks over a tables and stares at Yurilivich.  Meanwhile, Lutz takes o compass.  He checks his reading then starts shifting the slightly.  Peter looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter shrugs his shoulders indicating he doesn't.  The President walks over to Peter's table and starts his time Peter makes a move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Andy sit at a table with DOCTOR ALAN FULTON.  A thin man in his fifties.  Doctor Fulton studies the photographs, then looks up at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must understand that this is not my field?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't mine either but I can tell this guy's crazy.  That's your business ain't it, doc?  You deal with crazy people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I deal with people with problems... and there are all different types of problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Fulton, we don't have a budget out here like Seattle.  We can't afford to hire outside Psychological help. I'll take whatever you can give me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he appears to be acting out some kind of fantasy.  We're talking about a deeply disturbed person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could someone this disturbed give the appearance of being normal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a suspect but no hard evidence.  If you met him do you think you could tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (askance at Andy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's... disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible, but not likely.  There's only one opinion I can offer with any certainty. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to kill again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is on the bench press straining to finish his set. Although he is clearly tired, it's a battle of will over muscle.  Although his face is red, veins bugling, he does three last presses, then replaces the bar.  He sits up an buries his face in his towel.  When he looks up he sees..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATHY SHEPPARD, a beautiful woman in her twenties is stan against the wall, her eyes on him.  Peter smiles at her. smiles back, then walks out of the room.  Peter lays back and starts another set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters, a towel wrapped around his waist.  He takes steps into the room, then stops when he sees Kathy throug steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  I thought it was empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits down a few feet from her.  Steam swirls throug room.  Kathy's eyes drift over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HER POV:  Beads of sweat roll down his chest and stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter looks over at her, their eyes meet.  She looks away Peter closes his eyes and takes a few deep, meditative br Kathy looks over at him again.  As if sensing he is being watched Peter opens his eyes.  A beat.  Their eyes linger each others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your first time here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this hotel.  I stay here every time I visit my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you don't stay with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I love them, but they drive me crazy.  You know how parents are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you with the tournament?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you one of the players?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to learn how to play chess.  I don't have the patience for it.  When did you start playing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was very young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems like such a complicated game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.  You see your goal and you go after it.  Anything that gets in the way is an obstacle and must be destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds very violent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chess is a reflection of life.  Life is violent.  The strong win.  The weak perish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but you enjoy being the stronger one? You like the control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're asking me if I'm passionate about what I do, the answer is yes. Without passion, nothing moves us. What's your passion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a very personal question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  This is going to be a very polite conversation.  What shall we discuss?  The weather?  Movies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you disappointed that I won't answer you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had just hoped there would be more substance to the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought opening too quickly was a fatal mistake in chess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always open quickly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we talking about me, or chess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each circumstance requires a different tactic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I hope you remember that tomorrow when you play Krikorian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stares at Kathy for a moment.  She's made a mistake she knows it.  She stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think I've had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting too hot in here for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feigns a smile and starts towards the door.  Suddenly hand shoots out, grabbing her arm.  She freezes.  Peter s up, his body trapping her between him and door, his lips touching her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  I just came in for a steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spins her around.  They are face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you?  A reporter?  Just how far were you going to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Peter lets her go and backs off.  She opens the and leaves.  Peter smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy walks across the grounds.  Frank catches up with he walks along side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what?  I told you this was a stupid idea.  You can't learn anything from someone in a few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't pick up any vibes from the guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a psychologist, Frank... not a psychic.  What's this all about anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Dr. Fulton tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only that you wanted someone from the institute to talk to Sanderson for some case you're working on.  What'd he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think he did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think he could be a suspect in a murder investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stops dead in her tracks and stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl that was killed last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's silence tells her she's right.  She stares at him moment, then walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy is BANGING loudly on the front door.  A moment late is answered by Dr. Fulton.  In the b.g a DINNER PARTY is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Fulton sits on the couch.  Kathy paces the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might not have done it had you known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damn right!  I'm a child psychologist and you send me into a room with someone who could be a murderer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind keeping your voice down? I have guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well we wouldn't want to disturb your guests, would we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police came to me for help.  What could I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have been honest with me for starters.  We work together.  I have to be able to trust you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admit I handled it badly.  Sanderson wasn't going to talk to me... but you're young, attractive--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the same type as the girl who got killed.  Jesus, Alan, the guy could be a psychopath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They asked who would be best suited for this and you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't patronize me!  You sent me into a potentially dangerous situation and didn't warn me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks to the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It worked out alright, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the GUESTS are sitting at the dinner table, eating so They stare at Kathy.  Fulton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the guests)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I would have said to the chef if I caught him shaving over the soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out.  Slowly, several of the GUESTS lower the s spoons and push their bowls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LOBBY appears empty.  One of the office doors opens a CHRISTIE EASTMAN, A young, attractive woman, comes out ca a stack of files.  She walks out of the lobby, LOCKING th behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the car descends, Christie looks through one of the fi She turns a page and the file falls to the floor.  She be down to pick it up.  As she does the elevator stops and t doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of black boots stand before her.  She looks up to MAN in his fifties.  He smiles and gets in.  The doors cl and the car starts down again.  Christie stares at the fl indicator, somewhat unnerved by the man's presence.  The stops at the lobby and the man gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christie walks across the deserted parking lot towards he She HEARS a SOUND and stops and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRISTIE'S POV:  As her eyes scan the desolate parking lo sees nothing unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christie starts to walk again.  She arrives at her car, g inside, then rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christie starts the car, then takes out a cigarette from pocket and lights it.  She takes a deep drag, then looks into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON REAR VIEW MIRROR:  From the back seat we see TWO EYES staring at her from behind a PORCELAIN MASK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns around.  Her face filled with fear.  FLASH!  Th screen is filled with BRIGHT LIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car drives up the gravel path and stops in front of the entrance.  Frank gets out and walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy is watching a young GIRL through a two-way mirror i next room as she plays and interacts with dolls and toys. makes a few notes, then the door opens and Frank walks in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm busy right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy goes through a door into the observation room.  Thr the mirror we see her kneel down next to the girl and smi She says something to her as she points to a door leading of the room.  The girl gives her a big hug.  A moment lat see Frank join her in the room.  He says something and th start to argue.  Kathy points towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON COMPUTER MONITOR:  A chess program.  A piece is The screen reads:  CHECKMATE!  YOU WIN.  PULL BACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is at the computer.  Jeremy sits beside him.  Frank over to Andy who is with a TECHNICIAN setting up tracing equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still think this is a crock of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a KNOCK at the door.  Andy opens it.  Kathy enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter looks at Frank, then Kathy with confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Sanderson, this is Doctor Sheppard.  She's a psychologist helping us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already met.  Haven't we... Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she smirks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you're still having problems with your openings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this Jeremy--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Edmonds.  I know.  You lost to Karpov in '82, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  However, that's not exactly how I prefer to be remembered. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going to get out of your way. Peter, I'll see you this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ASHTRAY:  A cigarette is snuffed out.  PULL BACK Andy finishes putting out his cigarette, then glances up Peter who is pacing back and forth.  Andy checks his watc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven oh six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Peter with a grin.  A beat as the two men sta each other.  The moment is broken as the PHONE RINGS LOUD Peter's head snaps towards the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, try to keep him on as long as you can.  Don't confront him.  Let him answer the questions I gave you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Technician starts his tape machine and tracing equipm Peter picks up his CORDLESS PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the CALLER'S distorted VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stalling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a second. (a beat, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very amateurish, Peter.  I'm surprised you would use such an obvious tactic. (there is anger in his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not an idiot!  Don't treat me as one!  I'll call you everyday... You get one minute, whether you put me on hold or talk is up to you!  Are you ready to play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Why did you kill Debi Rutlege?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To get your attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, only the path she chose to travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is trying to keep the conversation moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And -- what path is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have paths to follow.  You hope yours will lead you to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you write remember on the wall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's something you'll have to figure out for yourself.  Really, Peter, you can't expect me to answer such direct questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to think and that's why I'll win!  I'm already two points ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did another one last night.  You might have saved her, but you didn't want to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you got something to say to me, just come out and say it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy picks up the extension phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she you sonofabitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a chuckle from the Caller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... Detective Wagner.  I'm sorry but you'll have to get off the line and go back to your tracing equipment.  If I wanted to play the game with a moron I would have called you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank angrily motions Andy to get off.  Andy hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you want to know where I'm going to kill tonight, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wee Willie Winkie runs through the town.  Upstairs and downstairs in his nightgown.  Crawling through the window.  At the end of Miss Emma's street.  Her God has gone and left his home.  So her and I can meet."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead.  A beat.  Everyone reflects on what t have just heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Andy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your fuckin' mind picking up the phone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Technician)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  We'd have a better chance if we could tap in at the junction box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Mister Sanderson. (to Kathy and Andy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to go with you?  Maybe I can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright.  We'll take it from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy, Frank and Andy leave Peter's room and walk back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be an actor, Frank.  You looked like you were really mad.  The veins popping out on your neck was a really nice touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't mad at him for picking up the phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I told him to.  I wanted to make sure there was someone on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we heard him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could have been a tape.  A prerecorded conversation between Sanderson and himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A room set up to deal with the murder.  PHOTOGRAPHS are p to a cork board.  Frank is at a table with Kathy, Andy an Nolan.  On the chalkboard in the rhyme the Caller recited earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The F.B.I. has nothing remotely similar to this guy.  I think he's a first- timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check with the State.  If he's never killed outside of Washington the F.B.I. wouldn't have it.  Nolan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tapes their mouths shut.  We found traces of adhesive around the victims mouths.  We're doing a chemical analysis for components, but it's probably a standard brand you can buy in any hardware store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only two hardware stores on the whole Island.  We'll check that out. What about the blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a drop.  Maybe the guy works for the Red Cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks at Nolan askance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the fact that he views this as a game suggests that he is trying to prove some sense of superiority -- and the way he murders confirms a need to be in complete control of his victim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the way he arranged the body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would indicate he's playing out a fantasy.  Power-control killers usually fantasize about their actions long before they commit them.  Once they become a reality though, they reach a sense of euphoria and need to repeat the act to sustain it.  But, in all the research I've read on Serial Killers, I've never heard of one moving so fast. It's as if the game is the catalyst for the murders -- not the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Why disguise your voice if no one knows it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking the same thing.  He must be local.  It's logical for him to assume that the police would be there, but he recognized Andy's voice and called him by name. (points to the rhyme)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would think it's some type of clue as to where he's going to kill next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he call Sanderson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one of the best Chess players in the world.  Who better to play a game with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Andy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still having a problem with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I am.  I think he's playing us. If I was a killer and the police were trying to make a case against me, what better why to draw them off than to put their attention on someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sending yourself anonymous notes in the mail is one thing -- but who called him today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Maybe there's two of them.  Maybe he hired some Wino to make the calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're reaching a bit?  I think Sanderson should be in on this. There's a reason why the killer's calling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A UNIFORMED OFFICER KNOCKS and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, we found her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several BLACK and WHITE UNITS are parked in the rear of t building.  Frank and Andy walk up the loading dock steps silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body of CHRISTIE EASTMAN is laying on top of a large Her body has been draped tightly with a sheet and her arm folded across her chest.  Her face is deathly white and h been made up with the same clumsy makeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Written in blood on the wall behind her is:  EVENTUALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter paces back and forth waiting for the match to begin Yurilivich is sitting in a chair, watching Peter with a g Peter turns around and almost bumps into Lutz who is wear ridiculous hat with sheets of aluminium foil sticking out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're trying to control my thoughts. (points to the hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aluminium foil.  It repels the thought rays.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter stares at him.  In the b.g. Kathy enters, looks aro then walks over to Peter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They couldn't break the riddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think it was going to be easy? You think he was going to lay it out at your feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I offered my help this morning and Sedman turned me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're the key.  The one he wants to play the game with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't right now.  I've got a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could be dead after the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could be dead now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if she isn't?  Where are your priorities?  You have to think between someone's life and a chess game? (raising her voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl he killed last night was only twenty one years old!  He dumped her body behind a warehouse like a sack of garbage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is now staring at Kathy and Peter who are starin each other.  In the b.g. The President appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GRANDMASTERS walk onto stage as Peter and Kathy conti stare at each other.  A beat.  Peter starts to move towar stage.  Kathy takes a step after him.  She takes a envelo from her jacket pocket and puts it into Peter's jacket po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter sits across from GRANDMASTER KRIKORIAN.  He makes a then hits his timer.  On the BOARD behind him the move is duplicated.  Krikorian studies the board.  Peter is stari over the AUDIENCE deep in thought.  Krikorian makes a mov hits the timer.  Peter continues to stare, unaware that i his move.  A beat.  All eyes are on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter turns around and stares at the big board, then walk and makes a move.  Krikorian studies his position.  Peter reaches into his pocket for a cigarette.  He removes the envelope Kathy gave him, then his cigarettes.  A beat.  H stares at the envelope, flicking his finger against it. Krikorian looks up annoyed.  Peter opens the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON PHOTOGRAPHS:  We see several PHOTOGRAPHS of Chri Eastman before her death.  Peter turns through them.  Nex see the grisly PHOTOS taken at the crime scene.  He is a struggling to make a decision.  Krikorian makes a move. does not react.  He replaces the PHOTOS and stares at the envelope, then looks up at Krikorian who is watching him. beat.  Peter replaces the envelope in his pocket, then ma move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits with Frank and Andy.  Coffee cups litter with The nursery rhyme is written on the BLACKBOARD and reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Her God has gone and left his home?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone shakes there head indicating they don't understa reference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why these girls?  How does he pick them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank points to a LARGE MAP of the CITY on the wall, with RED PINS in different locations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the map)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it matters.  Last nights victim, Christie Eastman was found in a warehouse on the outskirts of town. The night before, Debi Rutlege was found in the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning, it looks like his victims are chosen at random.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter is standing in the doorway.  He enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it's a game.  All games have a strategy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you gotta do is look at the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His victims aren't random.  It only means that they appear to be random. There's a connection, we just have to find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter turns his attention to the blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you come up with on the riddle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Wee Willie Winkie runs though the street."  We think he might be making a reference to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, but I don't think so.  I think it's just a tease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs and downstairs in his night gown -- He could be saying the house he's picked is two stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he approaches a TWO STORY house.  The POV stops moving if to decide which way to go... then goes around the righ of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, Kathy, Frank and Andy continue to unravel the mess

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Crawling through the window"... We think that's how he's going to get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowbar is placed under a window and pried up until the breaks.  We see two GLOVED HANDS open the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter has taken his jacket off and is pacing the room.  K Frank and Andy stare at the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think he might be making a reference to drugs?  Miss Emma is a street term used by junkies for Morphine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could Emma be the name of the girl he's going to kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've checked.  There's no one with the last name of Emma on the Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's going to drug her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's killed both girls exactly the same way.  It's almost ritualistic.  Why would he change now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morpheus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not what -- who.  Morpheus.  The Greek God of dreams.  Look at the next line. "Her God has gone and left his home."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His home would be... Mount Olympus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call dispatch.  Double the patrols.  I want that area blanketed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Andy rush from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LORAINE OLSEN, a YOUNG, ATTRACTIVE GIRL in her twenties e the room and walks over to the CLOSET as she takes off he jacket.  She reaches for the DOORKNOB when the PHONE RING She hesitates for a moment, deciding whether to open the but decides to answer the phone first.  She walks over an picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?...  Oh hi Mom...  No I just got in...  No I haven't forgotten. Tomorrow, ten o'clock...  Yes... Yes... Okay, I'll see you in the morning. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, walks back to the CLOSET and opens the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is a large WALK-IN, the back filled with LONG HANGING DRE that almost reach the floor.  Below them is a row of SHOE neatly aligned on the floor.  Loraine hangs up her jacket takes off her shirt, then puts on a tee shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loraine finishes brushing her teeth.  She turns off the w but we still HEAR a DRIPPING SOUND.  She looks over at th tub with the SHOWER CURTAINS DRAWN.  She opens the curtai tightly turns the handle to stop the nozzle from leaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loraine sits on the edge of her bed and peels herself out her tight pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters the closet and hangs up her pants.  As she doe we see: Among the row of shoes is a pair of BLACK HIGH-TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loraine starts to leave.  The TENNIS SHOES move forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON LORAINE:  A GLOVED HAND reaches over and CLAMPS tightly over her mouth, muffling her SCREAM as,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLOSET DOOR is SLAMMED SHUT.  SILENCE.  A FLASH of li fills the frame of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colorful SHOPS and RESTURANTS line the street.  Peter gra HOT DOG from a VENDOR and takes a big bite, then looks at Kathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want to eat something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to walk agin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be a long night.  It could take hours before we know something.  You should try to eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't intentional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does what's going on bother you at all? Or are you just wearing your game face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another kind of game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but it is.  He's killing a person everyday and challenging us to catch him.  That's a game.  It has rules and objectives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you look at it so clinically?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your average cop.  They deal with death everyday.  If they let emotions get in the way it would cloud their judgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true -- but the emotion is still there.  They just learn to control it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?  Aren't there times when a young child is telling you a story so sad you just want to cry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  So, tell me about yourself.  Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did we get to that subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's best if we don't ask too many personal questions -- I want to keep things on a professional level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like in the steam room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not fair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to tell me you didn't feel something in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy is growing more uncomfortable by the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're projecting your own desires and reading more into what happened than what actually did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.  Spoken like a true psychologist.  When confronted with the prospect of your own reality, hide behind quotations.  What is that Masters and Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tension breaks.  Kathy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to win every point, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to know if you're involved with anyone? (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something?  Do your colleagues know if you're involved or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I work with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you working with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy smiles again, amused by Peter's tactics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm not involved. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I plan on keeping it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy walks off, leaving Peter staring after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy, Frank and Andy are in the room with Nolan.  Nolan his knees at the base of a window.  On the floor beside h a RULER and a SHEET OF RUBBERIZED PAPER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where he forced his way in.  We found some fibers on the windowsill, probably particles of clothing that rubbed off when he climbed through. I'll know more once I get it under the microscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I've saved the best for last. Andy, hit the lights, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy looks for the light switch.  Kathy realizes she's st in front of it and moves out of the way.  Andy turns off lights and the room goes dark.  Nolan turns on a FLASHLIG gets down on his knees, then SHINES the LIGHT at a LOW AN across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FLOOR - CLOSE SHOT:  We can clearly see the impressio SHOE PRINT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tennis shoe.  Pretty old by the individual characteristics.  About a size ten or eleven.  This guy is big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy points to a JAGGED LINE in the impression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know.  Looks like a cut or a gash in the sole of the shoe.  We'll blow it up back at the lab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Andy and Kathy follow Nolan towards the bedroom. stops and taps Kathy on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we go in I gotta tell you this isn't going to be pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.  I've seen the photo's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't no photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Andy  and Kathy enter the room.  Loraine's body is laying on the bed, her appearance is like all the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wall written in blood is: REVENGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy stares at the sight, horrified.  She starts to gag runs from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long she been dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say at least eighteen hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means she was dead before we even finished figuring out the message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or before Sanderson ever showed up to help us with the riddle.  He figured it out pretty quick, didn't he?  Maybe it's not to hard if you wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters in his SWEATS to find Erica, Jeremy and Davi sitting around a computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica runs over to him and gives him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jeremy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our computer went on the fritz again. David came up to fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, it's all fixed.  I also loaded up a program that'll analyze your games three hundred percent faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks over to the MONITOR.  A COMPUTER GAME is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I put a few games on for your daughter.  I hope you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got to go over Lutz's room now.  He thinks someone has tapped into his computer and is monitoring his practice games.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David picks up his bag and starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have something you want to say to David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me you'd take me over to Seattle today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, honey, I can't.  Not today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you promised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica stares at him sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She forces a smile for Jeremy's sake, then leaves the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got be here for the police when they come.  Then I've got to practise. In case you forgot I'm in the middle of a match right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always in the middle of a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be the best I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think you'd rather be the best chess player, than the best father.  Instead of thinking about what kind of day your daughter had, you would rather think about the Sicilian Najdorf opening or a counter to the Tartokover Bondarevsky System. (Beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A relationship is not a chessboard. You can't walk away from it and come back whenever you want and still expect all the pieces to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter enters from the bathroom wearing only his jeans.  H over to his briefcase and starts to take out a paper.  He stops, then slowly takes out an OLD, WORN, ENVELOPE.  He at it. There is a KNOCK on the door.  Peter replaces the ENVELOPE. He opens the door to find a pale and shaken Kat She walks into  the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found the third girl.  Her name was Loraine Olsen.  I just came from the crime scene.  It was horrible.  How can anybody do something like that? You got anything to drink around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter walks over to the bar and pours her a brandy.  He b it over to her and sits beside her on the couch.  Kathy g it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell can I relax after seeing what I just saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you?  Unless you were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes lock for a moment, each probing the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I didn't mean that the way it sounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you didn't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Andy thinks you're doing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't that scare you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I think he's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter takes her hand and holds it in his.  There is a KNO the door.  Peter opens it to find Frank and Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter follows Frank and Andy as they walk down a utility hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damp and dark.  A large cavernous room built under the ho

dialogues.speaker: SEVERAL SMALLER ROOMS, OR ALCOVES, CONNECT TO THE MAIN RO
dialogues.text: THROUGH A SERIES OF JOINING DOORS.  FLORESCENT LIGHTS spa the ceiling cast long shadows through the room.  Large wa pipes and electrical mains run across the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Andy, Peter and Kathy enter.  Frank walks over to TECHNICIAN we saw before.  He is setting up his tracing equipment at the main TELEPHONE JUNCTION BOX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to a phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While we're down here all calls coming into Mr. Sanderson's room will be routed to extenion 611.  I've also--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS.  It echoes through the room.  Peter's fa tenses.  He walks over and picks it up.  A LOUDSPEAKER is activated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what I'm doing right now, Peter?  I'm looking at the name of the girl I'm going to kill tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a trace of anger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's the type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said you didn't know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I said!  She looks just like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really wish you'd stop trying to maneuver me.  I find it irritating, not to mention insulting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to play the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not playing very well.  There are clues all around you and you keep missing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter's frustration grows.  He decides to try a different

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, if you're just going to call up to gloat, I don't want to hear it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure there are other people who would be interested in what I have to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then call them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter slams down the phone.  Kathy, Frank and Andy are st that Peter would end the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see how much he wants to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE fills the room.  Peter stares at the phone expect A moment later it RINGS.  Peter waits and lets it ring. Finally he answers it on the fourth ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just for that no hint today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?  You must have some idea of the pain you're causing people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pain?  Pain is just a state of mind. It's something you learn to live with. I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy hands Peter a note she has written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading the note)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you want these girls to feel your pain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I don't want to get into the psychological aspects of my actions. It would detract from the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't say it any better than Huxley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huxley's quote also says, "his play is always fair and just."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is mine, within the framework of my rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead.  Peter hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the hell do you think you're doing?  Slamming down the phone in the middle of the trace.
